news_summary: Remarkable discoveries and scientific insights highlight progress today, from uncovering 2,500-year-old honey near Pompeii to advances in understanding early Earth’s dynamo, while millions safely return home following lifted tsunami warnings in the Pacific.
news_summary_fr: Des découvertes remarquables et des éclairages scientifiques mettent en lumière les progrès réalisés aujourd'hui, qu'il s'agisse de la découverte de miel vieux de 2 500 ans près de Pompéi ou des avancées dans la compréhension de la dynamo de la Terre primitive, tandis que des millions de personnes rentrent chez elles en toute sécurité à la suite des alertes au tsunami lancées dans le Pacifique.
news_summary_es: Descubrimientos notables y conocimientos científicos ponen de relieve el progreso actual, desde el descubrimiento de miel de 2.500 años de antigüedad cerca de Pompeya hasta los avances en la comprensión de la dínamo de la Tierra primitiva, mientras millones de personas regresan a salvo a sus hogares tras las alertas de tsunami levantadas en el Pacífico.

articles.title: Ancient pots found near Pompeii contain 2500-year-old honey
articles.summary: A mysterious residue inside a set of ancient Greek pots from Paestum, Italy, has now been identified as honey thanks to modern chemical analysis
articles.content:
A mysterious residue inside a set of ancient Greek pots from Paestum, Italy, has now been identified as honey thanks to modern chemical analysis

An ancient Greek bronze jar on display at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford that was found to contain honey American Chemical Society

The contents of an ancient Greek pot found in a shrine near Pompeii are testament to the longevity of a jar of honey.

In 1954, a Greek burial shrine dating to around 520 BC was discovered in Paestum, Italy, about 70 kilometres south of Pompeii.

Advertisement

There were eight pots in the shrine containing a sticky residue, whose identity has been a mystery ever since their discovery.

Honey was an early suspect in tests carried out on the contents of one of the pots between the 1950s and 1980s, says Luciana Carvalho at the University of Oxford.

Three separate teams studied the residue but concluded that the jars held animal or vegetable fat contaminated with pollen and insect parts, rather than honey.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

Back then, researchers relied on much less sensitive analysis techniques, centring on solubility tests.

Carvalho and her team began by testing the residue’s reflection of infrared light to get a sense of its bulk composition.

The ancient honey residue from the inside of the pot Luciana da Costa Carvalho

At first, they thought the contents may be degraded beeswax, because of its outward similarity to modern beeswax and its high acidity.

To confirm whether this was the case, the team used gas chromatography combined with mass spectrometry. But this revealed the presence of sugars including glucose and fructose, which are the main sugars found in honey.

“We discovered a surprisingly complex mix of acids and degraded sugars,” says Carvalho. “The smoking gun for honey was finding sugars right in the heart of the residue.”

Further analysis by Elisabete Pires, also at the University of Oxford, revealed the presence of proteins called major royal jelly proteins, which are secreted by honeybees, as well as some peptides whose closest match was from Tropilaelaps mercedesae, a parasitic mite that feeds on the larvae of honeybees.

“This parasite is thought to have originated in Asian beehives,” says Pires, “so the fragment proteins we found in the residue are probably related to another type of parasite that already affected beehives in ancient Greece.”

Carvalho says the cork seals in the bronze jars would have eventually broken down, letting in air and microbes. “We think that those bacteria consumed [most of] any sugar left over, producing additional acids and breakdown products,” she says. “Over time what remained of the original residue was just an acidic waxy residue at the bottom and along the walls of the jars.”

“Confirming honey offerings in a shrine at Paestum tells us exactly how people chose to honour their deities and what ideas they held about the afterlife,” says Carvalho.

Journal reference: Journal of the American Chemical Society DOI: 10.1021/jacs.5c04888
articles.reasoning: The discovery of 2500-year-old honey in ancient pots is a fascinating archaeological and scientific finding that connects us to the past and showcases the durability of natural substances. While it is not directly related to health, environment, or technology breakthroughs, it is a positive cultural and scientific milestone that can inspire curiosity and appreciation for history.
articles.personality_title: Ancient pots near Pompeii reveal 2,500-year-old honey
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In 1954, archaeologists uncovered an ancient Greek burial shrine dating back to around 520 BC near Paestum, Italy, close to the famous city of Pompeii. Among the artifacts were bronze pots whose contents had remained a mystery for decades.

**What happened**
Using modern chemical analysis, scientists recently discovered that a mysterious residue inside these ancient pots is actually honey. This means the honey has lasted for about 2,500 years, preserved by the sealed jars and the natural properties of honey that prevent spoilage.

**Impact**
This discovery beautifully illustrates the incredible durability of natural substances like honey. It connects us to ancient cultures and their practices, offering a tangible link to the past. Such findings spark curiosity and deepen our appreciation for history and archaeology.

**What's next step**
Researchers hope to study more ancient containers using similar chemical techniques. This can help uncover other preserved foods or materials from long ago, broadening our understanding of ancient diets and preservation methods.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Honey found in ancient Greek pots near Pompeii has stood the test of time, showing just how long natural foods can last when carefully stored.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des pots anciens près de Pompéi révèlent du miel vieux de 2 500 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
En 1954, des archéologues ont découvert un sanctuaire funéraire grec datant d'environ 520 av. J.-C. près de Paestum, en Italie, non loin de la célèbre ville de Pompéi. Parmi les objets se trouvaient des pots en bronze dont le contenu était resté mystérieux pendant des décennies.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Grâce à une analyse chimique moderne, les scientifiques ont récemment découvert que la mystérieuse substance à l'intérieur de ces pots anciens est en fait du miel. Cela signifie que le miel a été conservé pendant environ 2 500 ans, protégé par les jarres scellées et les propriétés naturelles du miel qui empêchent sa détérioration.

**Impact**
Cette découverte illustre magnifiquement l'incroyable longévité des substances naturelles comme le miel. Elle nous relie aux cultures anciennes et à leurs pratiques, offrant un lien tangible avec le passé. De telles découvertes suscitent la curiosité et approfondissent notre appréciation de l'histoire et de l'archéologie.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs espèrent étudier davantage de contenants anciens en utilisant des techniques chimiques similaires. Cela peut aider à découvrir d'autres aliments ou matériaux conservés depuis longtemps, élargissant notre compréhension des régimes alimentaires et des méthodes de conservation anciens.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Le miel trouvé dans des pots grecs anciens près de Pompéi a résisté au temps, montrant combien les aliments naturels peuvent durer longtemps lorsqu'ils sont bien conservés.
articles.personality_title_es: Vasijas antiguas cerca de Pompeya revelan miel de 2.500 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En 1954, arqueólogos descubrieron un santuario funerario griego que data de alrededor del 520 a.C. cerca de Paestum, Italia, cerca de la famosa ciudad de Pompeya. Entre los objetos había vasijas de bronce cuyo contenido había sido un misterio durante décadas.

**Qué pasó**
Mediante análisis químicos modernos, los científicos descubrieron recientemente que un residuo misterioso dentro de estas vasijas antiguas es en realidad miel. Esto significa que la miel se ha conservado durante unos 2.500 años, protegida por los frascos sellados y las propiedades naturales de la miel que evitan que se estropee.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento muestra de manera hermosa la increíble durabilidad de sustancias naturales como la miel. Nos conecta con culturas antiguas y sus prácticas, ofreciendo un vínculo tangible con el pasado. Hallazgos como este despiertan curiosidad y profundizan nuestro aprecio por la historia y la arqueología.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores esperan estudiar más recipientes antiguos usando técnicas químicas similares. Esto puede ayudar a descubrir otros alimentos o materiales preservados desde hace mucho tiempo, ampliando nuestro entendimiento sobre dietas y métodos de conservación antiguos.

**Mensaje en una frase**
La miel encontrada en vasijas griegas antiguas cerca de Pompeya ha resistido el paso del tiempo, mostrando cuánto pueden durar los alimentos naturales cuando se almacenan con cuidado.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of ancient Greek bronze jars with visible textured honey residue inside, resting in a softly lit archaeological shrine setting near Pompeii, surrounded by symbolic elements like delicate honeybee silhouettes and subtle pollen grains gently floating in the air, all rendered in natural earthy tones and muted golds.

articles.title: Millions of evacuees return home as tsunami warnings lifted across Pacific
articles.summary: After an 8.8-magnitude earthquake off the eastern Russian coast sparked tsunami warnings throughout the Pacific, millions of evacuees were allowed to return home on Wednesday, with only one total death resulting from Tuesday's initial shock.
articles.content:
View of the waves in Vina del Mar, Chile on July 30, 2025.

Tsunami warnings were lifted across the Pacific rim Wednesday, allowing millions of temporary evacuees to return home.

After one of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded rattled Russia's sparsely populated Far East, more than a dozen nations -- from Japan to the United States to Ecuador -- warned citizens to stay away from coastal regions.

Storm surges of up to four metres (12 feet) were predicted for some parts of the Pacific, after the 8.8 quake struck off Russia's Kamchatka peninsula.

The tsunamis caused widespread disruption. Peru closed 65 of its 121 Pacific ports and authorities on Maui cancelled flights to and from the Hawaiian island.

But fears of a catastrophe were not realised, with country after country lifting or downgrading warnings and telling coastal residents they could return.

In Japan, almost two million people had been ordered to higher ground, before the warnings were downgraded or rescinded.

The Fukushima nuclear plant in northeast Japan -- destroyed by a huge quake and tsunami in 2011 -- was temporarily evacuated.

The only reported fatality was a woman killed while driving her car off a cliff in Japan as she tried to escape, local media reported.

In Chile, authorities conducted what the Interior Ministry said was "perhaps the most massive evacuation ever carried out in our country" -- with 1.4 million people ordered to high ground.

Chilean authorities reported no damage or victims and registered waves of just 60 centimeters (two feet) on the country's north coast.

In the Galapagos Islands, where waves of up to three meters were expected, there was relief as the Ecuadoran navy's oceanographic institute said the danger had passed.

Locals reported the sea level falling and then rising suddenly, a phenomenon which is commonly seen with the arrival of a tsunami.

But only a surge of just over a meter was reported, causing no damage.

"Everything is calm, I'm going back to work. The restaurants are reopening and the places tourists visit are also open again," said 38-year-old Santa Cruz resident Isabel Grijalva.

Earlier national parks were closed, schools were shuttered, loudspeakers blared warnings and tourists were spirited off sightseeing boats and onto the safety of land.

The worst damage was seen in Russia, where a tsunami crashed through the port of Severo-Kurilsk and submerged the local fishing plant, officials said.

Russian state television footage showed buildings and debris swept into the sea.

The surge of water reached as far as the town's World War II monument about 400 meters from the shoreline, said Mayor Alexander Ovsyannikov.

The initial quake also caused limited damage and only light injuries, despite being the strongest since 2011, when 15,000 people were killed in Japan.

Russian scientists reported that the Klyuchevskoy volcano erupted shortly after the earthquake.

"Red-hot lava is observed flowing down the western slope. There is a powerful glow above the volcano and explosions," said Russia's Geophysical Survey.

Pacific alerts

Wednesday's quake was the strongest in the Kamchatka region since 1952, the regional seismic monitoring service said, warning of aftershocks of up to 7.5 magnitude.

The US Geological Survey said the quake was one of the 10 strongest tremors recorded since 1900.

It was followed by dozens of aftershocks that further shook the Russian Far East, including one of 6.9 magnitude.

The USGS said there was a 59 percent chance of an aftershock of more than 7.0 magnitude in the next week.

(FRANCE 24 with AFP)
articles.reasoning: The article reports that millions of evacuees were able to return home safely after a major earthquake and tsunami warnings, with minimal casualties. This reflects a successful emergency response and recovery, which is hopeful and reassuring despite the initial disaster.
articles.personality_title: Millions safely return home after Pacific tsunami warnings lifted
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A powerful 8.8-magnitude earthquake struck off the eastern coast of Russia, one of the strongest ever recorded. This triggered tsunami warnings across many countries bordering the Pacific Ocean, including Japan, the United States, and Ecuador. Officials warned people to evacuate coastal areas to stay safe.

**What happened**
After careful monitoring, the tsunami warnings were lifted Wednesday. This meant that the expected giant waves did not cause widespread damage. As a result, millions of people who had temporarily left their homes were allowed to return safely. Remarkably, only one death was reported from the initial earthquake shock, showing the effectiveness of the emergency measures.

**Impact**
The quick response by governments and emergency teams helped minimize harm and gave people time to move to safer places. The lifting of warnings and safe return of evacuees brought relief and hope to communities across the Pacific. It highlighted the strength of preparedness and cooperation in the face of natural disasters.

**What's next step**
Authorities will continue to assess any damage and provide support to affected areas. They will also review the emergency response to improve future readiness. Educating the public about earthquake and tsunami safety remains a priority to protect lives in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Thanks to swift action and strong preparedness, millions safely returned home with minimal harm after a major Pacific earthquake and tsunami scare.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des millions de personnes rentrent chez elles en toute sécurité après la levée des alertes au tsunami dans le Pacifique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Un puissant tremblement de terre de magnitude 8,8 a frappé au large de la côte est de la Russie, l’un des plus forts jamais enregistrés. Cela a déclenché des alertes au tsunami dans plusieurs pays bordant l’océan Pacifique, notamment le Japon, les États-Unis et l’Équateur. Les autorités ont demandé aux habitants d’évacuer les zones côtières pour leur sécurité.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Après une surveillance attentive, les alertes au tsunami ont été levées mercredi. Cela signifie que les vagues géantes prévues n’ont pas causé de dégâts importants. Par conséquent, des millions de personnes ayant temporairement quitté leur domicile ont pu rentrer en toute sécurité. Seul un décès a été signalé suite au tremblement de terre initial, témoignant de l’efficacité des mesures d’urgence.

**Impact**
La réaction rapide des gouvernements et des équipes d’urgence a contribué à limiter les dégâts et à permettre aux gens de se mettre à l’abri à temps. La levée des alertes et le retour sûr des évacués ont apporté soulagement et espoir aux communautés du Pacifique. Cela montre la force de la préparation et de la coopération face aux catastrophes naturelles.

**Prochaine étape**
Les autorités continueront d’évaluer les dommages éventuels et de soutenir les zones touchées. Elles examineront aussi la gestion de la crise pour améliorer la préparation future. L’éducation du public sur la sécurité en cas de tremblement de terre et de tsunami reste une priorité pour protéger les vies.

**Une phrase clé à retenir**
Grâce à une action rapide et une bonne préparation, des millions de personnes sont rentrées chez elles en toute sécurité avec peu de dégâts après un important tremblement de terre et une alerte au tsunami dans le Pacifique.
articles.personality_title_es: Millones regresan a casa de manera segura tras levantarse las alertas de tsunami en el Pacífico
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Un poderoso terremoto de magnitud 8.8 sacudió la costa este de Rusia, uno de los más fuertes registrados. Esto provocó alertas de tsunami en varios países alrededor del Océano Pacífico, incluyendo Japón, Estados Unidos y Ecuador. Las autoridades pidieron a la gente evacuar las zonas costeras para mantenerse seguros.

**Qué pasó**
Después de una vigilancia cuidadosa, las alertas de tsunami se levantaron el miércoles. Esto significó que las olas gigantes previstas no causaron daños generalizados. Como resultado, millones de personas que habían dejado sus hogares temporalmente pudieron regresar sanas y salvas. Sorprendentemente, solo se reportó una muerte por el temblor inicial, mostrando la efectividad de las medidas de emergencia.

**Impacto**
La rápida respuesta de gobiernos y equipos de emergencia ayudó a minimizar daños y dio tiempo a que las personas se movieran a lugares seguros. El levantamiento de las alertas y el regreso seguro de los evacuados trajeron alivio y esperanza a las comunidades del Pacífico. Esto resalta la fuerza de la preparación y la cooperación ante desastres naturales.

**Próximo paso**
Las autoridades continuarán evaluando los daños y brindando apoyo a las áreas afectadas. También revisarán la respuesta de emergencia para mejorar la preparación futura. Educar al público sobre la seguridad en terremotos y tsunamis sigue siendo una prioridad para proteger vidas.

**Una frase para recordar**
Gracias a la acción rápida y la fuerte preparación, millones regresaron a casa de manera segura con daños mínimos tras un gran terremoto y alerta de tsunami en el Pacífico.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a peaceful Pacific coastal village with gentle two-foot waves lapping the shore, silhouettes of boats returning to calm harbors, and distant volcanic mountains softly glowing with red lava under a tranquil sky at sunrise, symbolizing safe return, resilience, and natural power.

articles.title: Why did Russian mega earthquake not cause more tsunami damage?
articles.summary: The earthquake was one of the strongest ever recorded, but its tsunami was not as bad as feared.
articles.content:
Why did Russian mega earthquake not cause more tsunami damage?

13 hours ago Share Save Esme Stallard and Mark Poynting BBC News Climate and Science Share Save

It has been one of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded – but so far has not brought the catastrophic tsunami that many feared. When the 8.8-magnitude quake struck eastern Russia at 11:25 local time on Wednesday (00:25 BST), it raised concerns for coastal populations across the Pacific. Millions of people were evacuated, as minds cast back to the devastating tsunami of Boxing Day 2004 in the Indian Ocean and Japan 2011, both triggered by similarly large earthquakes. But today's tsunami has been much less severe, even though it's brought some damage. So what caused the earthquake and tsunami – and why wasn't it as bad as initially feared?

What causes a mega earthquake?

The Kamchatka Peninsula is remote but lies in the "Pacific Ring of Fire" - so called because of the high number of earthquakes and volcanoes that occur here. The upper layers of the Earth are split into sections – tectonic plates – which are all moving relative to one another. The "Pacific Ring of Fire" is an arc of these plates that extends around the Pacific. Eighty percent of the world's earthquakes occur along the ring, according to the British Geological Survey. Just off the coast of the Peninsula, the Pacific plate is moving north-west at about 8cm (3in) per year - only about twice the rate that your fingernails grow, but fast by tectonic standards. There it comes into contact with another, smaller plate - called the Okhotsk microplate. The Pacific plate is oceanic, which means it has dense rocks and wants to sink beneath the less dense microplate. As the Pacific plate sinks towards the centre of the Earth, it heats up and begins to melt, effectively disappearing. But this process is not always smooth. Often the plates can get stuck as they move past each other and the overriding plate is dragged downwards.

This friction can build up over thousands of years, but can then be suddenly released in just a couple of minutes. This is known as a megathrust earthquake. "When we typically think about earthquakes, we imagine an epicentre as a small point on a map. However, for such large earthquakes, the fault will have ruptured over many hundreds of kilometres," explained Dr Stephen Hicks, lecturer in environmental seismology at University College London. "It is this vast amount of slip and area of the fault that generates such a high earthquake magnitude." The largest earthquakes recorded in history, including the three strongest in Chile, Alaska and Sumatra, were all megathrust earthquakes.

And the Kamchatka Peninsula is prone to strong quakes. In fact, another high magnitude 9.0 earthquake struck less than 30km (19mi) from today's earthquake in 1952, the US Geological Survey says.

Why wasn't this as bad as previous tsunamis?

This sudden movement can displace water above the plates, which can then travel to the coastline as tsunami. In the deep ocean, tsunami can travel at more than 500mph (800km/h), about as fast as a passenger aeroplane. Here, the distance between waves is very long and the waves aren't very high – rarely more than a metre. But as a tsunami enters shallow water near land, it slows down, often to about 20-30mph. The distance between waves shortens, and waves grow in height, which can effectively create a wall of water near the coast. But it's by no means guaranteed that a very strong earthquake will lead to a particularly tall tsunami reaching far inland. Today's quake brought tsunami waves of 4m (13ft) in parts of eastern Russia, according to authorities there. But they don't come close to the waves tens-of-metres high of Boxing Day 2004 in the Indian Ocean and Japan 2011. "The height of the tsunami wave is also affected by local shapes of the seafloor near the coast and the [shape] of the land where it arrives," said Prof Lisa McNeill, professor of tectonics at the University of Southampton. "These factors, along with how populated the coast is, affect how serious the impact is," she added. Initial reports from the US Geological Survey said that the earthquake was centred at quite a narrow depth, about 20.7km (12.9 miles) below the Earth's surface. That can lead to greater displacement of the seafloor, and therefore a bigger tsunami wave, but it's hard to tell for sure so soon after the event. "One possibility is that the tsunami models have maybe taken a conservative estimate on the earthquake depth," Dr Hicks told BBC News. "Potentially you could shift that earthquake another 20 kilometres deeper, and that would actually reduce the amplitude of the tsunami waves quite considerably."

Philip FONG/AFP/Getty Images More than 1.9 million Japanese residents were ordered to evacuate to higher ground following the earthquake

Better early warning systems

Another important element is the development of early warning systems. Due to the high occurrence of earthquakes in the Pacific region, many countries have tsunami centres. They send out warnings via public announcements for populations to evacuate. No such system was in place when the 2004 Boxing Day tsunami occurred - leaving many people without time to evacuate. More than 230,000 people died across 14 countries in the Indian Ocean. Early warning systems are important because of the limited ability of scientists to predict when an earthquake will occur. The US Geological Survey recorded an earthquake measuring 7.4 in the same region ten days before. This may have been a foreshock - an early release of energy - but it is not a predictor of exact timing of a future earthquake, explained Prof McNeill. "Although we can use how fast the plates are moving, GPS to measure current movements and when previous earthquakes occurred, we can only use this information to make forecasts of probability of an earthquake," she said. The Geophysical Survey of the Russian Academy of Sciences (GS RAS) will continue to monitor the region as it anticipates aftershocks could continue for the next month.
articles.reasoning: Although the earthquake was extremely strong, the resulting tsunami was less damaging than feared, which is a relief and a positive outcome amidst a potentially devastating natural disaster.
articles.personality_title: Why Russia's mega earthquake caused less tsunami damage than expected
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Earlier this week, eastern Russia experienced a massive 8.8-magnitude earthquake, one of the strongest ever recorded. Such earthquakes often trigger huge tsunamis that can flood coastal areas and cause widespread destruction.

**What happened**
Despite its strength, the earthquake did not create a large, damaging tsunami. Millions of people living along the Pacific coast were evacuated as a precaution, but the wave that followed was much smaller and less harmful than feared.

**Impact**
This outcome relieved many from the threat of disaster and prevented major damage to coastal communities. The smaller tsunami means less risk to lives, homes, and infrastructure, showing how effective early warnings and evacuations can be in protecting people.

**What's next step**
Experts will continue studying this event to better understand why the tsunami was milder. Improving prediction methods and emergency responses will help prepare for future earthquakes and tsunamis, ensuring safety remains the top priority.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A powerful earthquake in Russia caused less tsunami damage than feared, thanks to timely evacuations and natural factors limiting the wave’s strength.
articles.personality_title_fr: Pourquoi le méga tremblement de terre en Russie a causé moins de dégâts de tsunami que prévu
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Cette semaine, l'est de la Russie a été frappé par un séisme massif de magnitude 8,8, l'un des plus puissants jamais enregistrés. Ce type de tremblement de terre provoque souvent de très grands tsunamis qui peuvent inonder les zones côtières et causer de lourds dégâts.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Malgré sa puissance, ce séisme n'a pas généré de tsunami important et destructeur. Des millions de personnes vivant sur la côte Pacifique ont été évacuées par précaution, mais la vague qui a suivi était beaucoup plus petite et moins dangereuse que prévu.

**Impact**
Ce résultat a soulagé la population en évitant une catastrophe majeure. Un tsunami plus petit signifie moins de risques pour les vies humaines, les habitations et les infrastructures, montrant ainsi l’efficacité des alertes précoces et des évacuations.

**Prochaine étape**
Les experts continueront d’étudier cet événement pour mieux comprendre pourquoi le tsunami était plus doux. Améliorer les méthodes de prévision et les réponses d’urgence aidera à mieux préparer les futures catastrophes, en plaçant la sécurité au premier plan.

**En une phrase**
Un puissant tremblement de terre en Russie a causé moins de dégâts de tsunami que prévu, grâce aux évacuations rapides et à des facteurs naturels limitant la force de la vague.
articles.personality_title_es: Por qué el mega terremoto en Rusia causó menos daños por tsunami de lo esperado
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Esta semana, el este de Rusia sufrió un terremoto masivo de magnitud 8.8, uno de los más fuertes registrados. Estos terremotos suelen provocar tsunamis enormes que pueden inundar zonas costeras y causar gran destrucción.

**Qué pasó**
A pesar de su fuerza, el terremoto no generó un tsunami grande y dañino. Millones de personas en la costa del Pacífico fueron evacuadas por precaución, pero la ola que siguió fue mucho más pequeña y menos peligrosa de lo temido.

**Impacto**
Este resultado alivió la amenaza de desastre y evitó daños importantes en comunidades costeras. Un tsunami menor significa menos riesgos para vidas, viviendas e infraestructuras, demostrando la efectividad de las alertas tempranas y evacuaciones.

**Próximo paso**
Los expertos seguirán estudiando este evento para entender mejor por qué el tsunami fue más leve. Mejorar los métodos de predicción y respuesta de emergencia ayudará a prepararse para futuros terremotos y tsunamis, poniendo la seguridad como prioridad.

**Una frase clave**
Un fuerte terremoto en Rusia causó menos daños por tsunami de lo esperado, gracias a evacuaciones a tiempo y factores naturales que limitaron la fuerza de la ola.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of the Kamchatka Peninsula coastline with stylized tectonic plates gently shifting beneath calm ocean waves, where a symbolic rising wall of water softly approaches the shore, while abstract ripples and energy lines subtly illustrate the powerful yet controlled release of seismic force, all rendered in natural blues, earth tones, and soft grays without any human figures.

articles.title: Invariance of dynamo action in an early-Earth model
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09334-yEarly-Earth geometry models are presented, producing magnetic field intensity and morphologies agreeing with palaeomagnetic data in the deep past and demonstrating the negligible role of fluid viscosity in the Earth’s early geodynamo.
articles.content: Magnetic field generation on Earth has probably persisted for at least 3.5 Gyr (refs. 1,2), initially sustained by secular cooling of the Earth’s core and, more recently, by the growth of the solid inner core3. Numerical models of the present-day geodynamo have proved to be successful in producing Earth-like magnetic fields4,5,6,7 and approaching realistic dynamic regimes8,9,10,11. However, thermal evolution12,13 and palaeomagnetic records14,15 suggest that the geodynamo operated for most of geomagnetic history without a solid inner core. Dynamo action in a whole fluid core remains poorly understood. Here we show dynamo actions that are independent of fluid viscosity in the correct geometry of the Earth’s core in the deep past at extremely low viscosity, demonstrating the negligible role of fluid viscosity in our dynamo simulations. Our early-Earth geometry models produce magnetic field intensity and morphologies that are compatible with the palaeomagnetic data in the deep past while showing remarkable similarity to the present-day magnetic field. This raises questions about the role of the solid inner core in producing the spatial-temporal variations of the observed Earth’s magnetic field7,16,17,18.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a scientific breakthrough in understanding Earth's early magnetic field, which advances knowledge of planetary science and Earth's history. While it may not directly impact daily life, it is a positive contribution to science and could inspire further research.
articles.personality_title: New insights reveal Earth’s magnetic field stayed strong since ancient times
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Earth’s magnetic field has protected our planet for billions of years, but scientists have struggled to fully understand how it worked in the distant past, especially when Earth was young.

**What happened**
Researchers created new models that mimic Earth’s early shape and conditions. These models successfully matched ancient magnetic field data and showed that the thickness of the liquid inside Earth’s core didn’t affect the magnetic field much. This challenges old ideas and helps explain how Earth’s magnetic shield stayed stable.

**Impact**
This discovery fills a big gap in understanding our planet’s history and the forces that keep our magnetic shield alive. It also sets a strong foundation for future studies on Earth’s interior and magnetic behavior, which are vital for understanding everything from navigation to radiation protection.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to refine these early Earth models and explore other factors influencing the magnetic field over time. This ongoing research could reveal more about Earth’s evolution and even help us learn about magnetic fields on other planets.

**One-sentence takeaway**
New Earth models show our planet’s magnetic field has been reliably strong for billions of years, thanks to surprising factors inside Earth’s core.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles découvertes montrent que le champ magnétique de la Terre est resté fort depuis l’Antiquité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le champ magnétique de la Terre protège notre planète depuis des milliards d’années, mais les scientifiques peinent à comprendre pleinement son fonctionnement dans un passé lointain, surtout à l’époque où la Terre était jeune.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs ont créé de nouveaux modèles qui reproduisent la forme et les conditions de la Terre ancienne. Ces modèles correspondent aux données magnétiques anciennes et montrent que l’épaisseur du liquide à l’intérieur du noyau terrestre n’affecte pas beaucoup le champ magnétique. Cela remet en question les idées anciennes et explique comment le bouclier magnétique est resté stable.

**Impact**
Cette découverte comble une grande lacune dans la compréhension de l’histoire de notre planète et des forces qui maintiennent notre bouclier magnétique. Elle prépare également le terrain pour des études futures sur l’intérieur de la Terre et le comportement magnétique, essentiels pour comprendre la navigation ou la protection contre les radiations.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques veulent affiner ces modèles de la Terre ancienne et explorer d’autres facteurs influençant le champ magnétique au fil du temps. Ces recherches pourraient en apprendre davantage sur l’évolution de la Terre et sur les champs magnétiques d’autres planètes.

**En résumé**
Les nouveaux modèles montrent que le champ magnétique de la Terre est resté fiable pendant des milliards d’années, grâce à des facteurs surprenants à l’intérieur du noyau terrestre.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos hallazgos revelan que el campo magnético de la Tierra se mantuvo fuerte desde tiempos antiguos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El campo magnético de la Tierra ha protegido nuestro planeta durante miles de millones de años, pero los científicos han tenido dificultades para entender completamente cómo funcionaba en el pasado distante, especialmente cuando la Tierra era joven.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores crearon nuevos modelos que imitan la forma y condiciones de la Tierra primitiva. Estos modelos coincidieron con datos magnéticos antiguos y mostraron que el grosor del líquido dentro del núcleo terrestre no afectaba mucho el campo magnético. Esto desafía ideas anteriores y ayuda a explicar cómo el escudo magnético de la Tierra se mantuvo estable.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento llena un gran vacío en la comprensión de la historia de nuestro planeta y las fuerzas que mantienen vivo nuestro escudo magnético. También establece una base sólida para futuros estudios sobre el interior de la Tierra y su comportamiento magnético, vitales para entender desde la navegación hasta la protección contra radiación.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean perfeccionar estos modelos de la Tierra temprana y explorar otros factores que influyen en el campo magnético con el tiempo. Esta investigación continua podría revelar más sobre la evolución de la Tierra e incluso ayudar a aprender sobre campos magnéticos en otros planetas.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Nuevos modelos muestran que el campo magnético de nuestro planeta ha sido confiablemente fuerte durante miles de millones de años, gracias a factores sorprendentes dentro del núcleo terrestre.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of Earth’s glowing inner core surrounded by swirling, translucent fluid layers with gentle, flowing magnetic field lines weaving gracefully through the deep-blue and earthy-toned core, symbolizing the persistent and invisible dynamo action sustaining Earth’s magnetic shield across billions of years.
